attributes.title: Unstructured Interviews
attributes.description: In this study, structured interviews versus unstructured interviews will be tested to determine 1) validity for job aptitude and performance and 2) confidence in candidate assessment ratings. The study will examine the relationship between predictive accuracy and the type of interview. First, participants will be divided into two groups. Second, the participants will view randomly assigned videos of five interviews recording from selected candidates. Third, participants will be asked to rate each aptitude for each candidate and assess the accuracy of their ratings based on pre-recorded data.

q1.value: Sophia Bologna, Darius Warfield, Matthew Willis, Taylor Hunter

q2.value:
Null, 1: The difference in predictive validity for job aptitude and performance is not significant between structured and unstructured interviews.
Alternative, 1: Structured interviews have a higher predictive validity in determining job aptitude and performance than unstructured interviews.
Null, 2: The guessed type of interview does not affect confidence in candidate assessment ratings.
Alternative, 2: The guessed type of interview provides greater confidence in candidate assessment ratings.
Null, 3: The reported confidence of rating assessment does not imply a significant difference in ratings.
Alternative, 3: The reported confidence of rating assessment implies a significant difference in ratings.

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)

question.value: A wealth of previous research literature has evidenced that structured interviews provide employers with the best insights into applicants.  However, many HR executives still hold the contrary belief: that unstructured interviews are the superior method in evaluating candidate fitness. In this study, we will measure the predictive value of both types of interviews by evaluating the predicted job aptitude of candidates by our study’s participants. To do this, we will show our participants one, randomly selected recording from each of our candidates. Each candidate will have had 2 recordings: one will be of a structured interview and one will be of an unstructured interview. Our candidates will have been in their jobs for at least 6 months, and will have been previously rated by their employer on their job performance. After watching each interview, our participants will rate the same assessment, which will be evaluated in relation to the employers’ rating. Also, we will assess the participants’ ability to identify the type of interview given to them at random and their confidence on rating the candidates. The candidates for our study will be chosen from a diverse set of fields and backgrounds, and will sign a consent release form for their interviews.

q8.value: Registration prior to any human observation of the data

question.value: For each candidate, we will record 2 videos: one of a structured interview and one of an unstructured interview. Before the experiment begins, each participant will be matched with a second participant, so there will be an even number of viewers in each group. In each trial, our groups of participants will be asked to watch a randomly-selected video for each of our candidates and asked to predict both their job aptitudes and future job performances. These predictions will be recorded on a form with multiple questions and a standard rating scale, which will be evaluated on the basis of their employer’s ratings. Also, participants will be prompted to guess the type of interview for each video and to rate their confidence for their judgments.

q11.value: Our study will have 5 candidates and 70 participants. The participants for our study will be students in an accredited psychology program who have taken at least one experimental design course and one organizational psychology course, which will be necessary in assessing knowledge of interview type and confidence of rating choice. Our sample of participants reflects the sample size of previous research in this area, and provides an adequate basis for evaluating significance in our calculation.

question.value: The manipulated variable for our study will be the type of video the participant is given: structured or unstructured.
The measured variables for our study will be candidate ratings, the perceived type of interview, and the confidence in ratings.
For this study, we will use a matched-pairs, one-sided t-test for evaluating hypotheses 1 and 3. For hypothesis 2, we will use a matched-pairs, two-sided t-test.

attributes.title: Autologous Craniofacial Fat Grafting in an Irradiated Field: A Systematic Review Protocol
attributes.description: There is conflicting data on whether fat transplantation in previously irradiated head and neck patients is beneficial in terms of volume depletion and improvement in both functional and aesthetic outcomes. Resorption is an important issue, especially in those exposed to radiotherapy that predisposes them to fibrotic changes, adiponecrosis and vessel depletion. There have been no previous systematic reviews that have looked into the role that fat transplantation can have in these patients long term. As such, our aim is to determine, among patients who have undergone previous head and neck radiation, does autologous facial fat grafting improve aesthetic and functional outcomes when compared to patients baseline facial contour?

q1.value: Jessica Gormley, Andrea Copeland, Mark mcrae

q2.value: If autologous facial fat grafting in a previously irradiated head and neck region is successful, then patients should have improved aesthetic and functional outcomes at their final follow up.

q3.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

q5.value: Blinding will be used during the screening process of titles/abstracts/full text to ensure the reviewers are not aware of the other's decision.

question.value: Our study is a systematic review of aesthetic and functional outcomes of craniofacial autologous fat grafting in a previously irradiated field. We will be completing our literature search from CENTRAL, CINAHL, Embase, Medline and Web of Science. Two reviewers will independently screen titles and abstracts, and a study will be included at this stage if one of the two reviewers chooses to include it. Full-text review will be completed by both reviewers independently. Any disagreements at the full-text stage will be discussed by reviewers until both are in agreement. For data collection, the reported outcomes will be specific to each of the studies included in our review. Reviewers will independently collect data from each of the studies included using the form. In order to assess the inter-reviewer agreement, the kappa (κ) statistic will be calculated for the title and abstract, as well as full text screening stages.  Due to a limited number of studies for this topic, as well as anticipated statistical and methodological heterogeneity, a meta-analysis is likely not warranted. We will summarize study characteristics using frequencies and percentages for categorical data and means and standard deviation or median and interquartile range for continuous data. We will summarize populations, interventions, comparison groups (if applicable) and reported outcomes in a table and we will present authors’ conclusions about the intervention graphically if relevant.

Primary Outcomes:
1. Percentage of volume depletion of fat graft
2. Facial contour symmetry compared to unaffected side
3. Functional range of motion

Secondary Outcomes:
1. Health related quality of life measures
2. Complications of procedure (ex. Nerve injury, fat necrosis, surgical site infection, donor site morbidity, etc.)
3. Collagen content of recipient site
4. Dermal thickness of recipient site
5. Vascular content of fat transfer of recipient site
A ratio of means method will be used to ensure scores from different measures are converted to the same scale. This is will allow for comparison and pooling of results in our analysis.

attributes.title: Reasons and Derogation of Opponents
attributes.description: Investigation of the role of reasons in person perception for the issue of universal healthcare.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Reasons and Derogation: Universal Healthcare with 4 Conditions

other.value:
As a secondary analysis, we will examine how many participants change their minds in each condition. We will compute cross-tabs analyses (2 x 4) to determine whether participants are more likely to change their minds (yes vs. no) when presented with reasons in opposition to their chosen option vs. when they are presented with reasons favoring their initial choices vs. no reasons whatsoever vs. when they are presented with all reasons for both sides. If significant, we will employ ransacking. 

We will also examine whether confidence changes as a function of condition (for all subjects and for the subset who do not change their minds). To this end, we will compute change in confidence scores (final confidence minus initial confidence) to serve as the DV. Condition will be the IV in the one-way ANOVA. If condition is significant in the ANOVA, we will conduct pair-wise post-hoc tests (LSD) between all possible conditions.

We will also compute the primary analyses with only the subset of participants who do not change their minds on their position.

sample.value: 900 participants will be recruited on Amazon's Mechanical Turk.

analyses.value: We will conduct four separate one-way ANOVAs to start. In each model, condition (4 levels of factor) will be the IV. In one model, the intellectual capabilities of opponents composite is the DV; in another model model, the moral character of opponents composite is the DV; in another model, the intellectual capabilities of people who choose the same position as them composite is the DV; in another model, the moral character of people who choose the same position as them composite is the DV. If condition is significant in any of the 4 ANOVAs, we will conduct post-hoc tests (LSD) to see which pair-wise conditions differ.

outliers.value:
For the three conditions in which participants consider reasons, they will see each reason individually, and then on the next page, they will do a fill-in-the-blank test for that reason. There are 4 different reasons for each side, so there are 4 fill-in-the-blank test questions for two experimental conditions, and 8 (4 on each side) fill-in-the-blank questions for the other experimental condition. Participants who incorrectly answer MORE THAN ONE fill-in-the-blank test per set of 4 reasons will be excluded from our analyses.

The other attention check occurs at the very end, and all participants will be presented with it. Participants will be asked the following: “Do you feel that you paid attention, avoided distractions, and took the survey seriously?” They respond by selecting one of the following: (1) no, I was distracted; (2) no, I had trouble paying attention; (3) no, I didn’t not take the study seriously; (4) no, something else affected my participation negatively; or (5) yes. Participants will be ensured that their responses will not affect their payment or their eligibility for future studies. Only those participants who select (5) will be included in any of our analyses.

dependent.value:
Participants will be asked to judge others who choose the other possible position about universal healthcare on the following:
-unintelligent (1 = strongly disagree, 5 = strongly agree)
-irrational (1 = strongly disagree, 5 = strongly agree)
-ignorant (1 = strongly disagree, 5 = strongly agree)
-bad moral character (1 = strongly disagree, 5 = strongly agree)
-unethical (1 = strongly disagree, 5 = strongly agree)
-immoral (1 = strongly disagree, 5 = strongly agree)

The first three items above will be averaged to form a composite measuring intellectual capabilities of opponents, and the latter three will be averaged to form a composite measuring moral character of opponents.

Participants will also be asked to judge others who choose the same position as them about universal healthcare on the following:
-unintelligent (1 = strongly disagree, 5 = strongly agree)
-irrational (1 = strongly disagree, 5 = strongly agree)
-ignorant (1 = strongly disagree, 5 = strongly agree)
-bad moral character (1 = strongly disagree, 5 = strongly agree)
-unethical (1 = strongly disagree, 5 = strongly agree)
-immoral (1 = strongly disagree, 5 = strongly agree)

The first three items above will be averaged to form a composite measuring intellectual capabilities of people who choose the same position as them, and the latter three will be averaged to form a composite measuring moral character of people who choose the same position as them.

conditions.value:
There are four conditions to which participants will be randomly assigned. In all conditions, participants will read neutral background information about universal healthcare, and then they will make a binary choice about whether they support or oppose a position. They will also rate confidence in the superiority of their binary decision on a 5-pt scale. 

After that, participants will be randomly assigned to one of four between-subjects conditions. In the first experimental condition, participants will be asked to consider 4 reasons for choosing the other possible position. In the other experimental condition, participants will be asked to consider 4 reasons favoring their chosen position. In another experimental condition, participants will be asked to consider 4 reasons for choosing the other possible position, and 4 reasons for favoring their chosen position. And in the control condition, participants see no reasons whatsoever.

Regardless of condition, all participants then choose their position on the same issue again (with the opportunity to change their minds), and they rate confidence again on the same scale.

hypothesis.value:
Primary Question: Does the consideration of reasons for an opposing (unchosen) position make participants less likely to derogate the intellectual capabilities and moral character of opponents (even when reasons favoring the chosen position are also presented along with the opposing reasons)--relative to being presented only with reasons favoring the same (chosen) position OR being presented with no reasons whatsoever? 

Secondary Question: Does the consideration of reasons for an opposing view, the same view, both sides, or no reasons alter how people perceive the intellectual capabilities and moral character of others who choose the same position as them.

subjects.text: Public Affairs, Public Policy and Public Administration

attributes.title: Reasons and Derogation of Opponents
attributes.description: We investigate whether people believe that their opponents lack good reasons for their positions (relative to those  who hold the same position as themselves) for each the two political issues: concealed carry of handguns and universal healthcare. We also investigate whether the more people believe their opponents lack good reasons for their positions, the more they derogate the intellectual capabilities and moral character of those opponents.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Reasons and Derogation: Underlying Assumptions for Concealed Carry and Universal Healthcare

sample.value: 250 participants will be recruited on Amazon's Mechanical Turk.

analyses.value:
Our first hypothesis is that people assume the following: those who hold the same position as them, relative to those who hold the other (unchosen) position, are more likely to have good reasons for holding their position. We will compute paired samples t-tests to address this hypothesis.

Our second hypothesis is that the extent to which participants believe their opponents have good reasons for their positions will predict derogation of the intellectual capabilities and moral character of opponents. To address this, we will conduct separate zero-order correlations, split by political issue, between our variables.

outliers.value: The attention check occurs at the very end, and all participants will be presented with it. Participants will be asked the following: “Do you feel that you paid attention, avoided distractions, and took the survey seriously?” They respond by selecting one of the following: (1) no, I was distracted; (2) no, I had trouble paying attention; (3) no, I didn’t not take the study seriously; (4) no, something else affected my participation negatively; or (5) yes. Participants will be ensured that their responses will not affect their payment or their eligibility for future studies. Only those participants who select (5) will be included in any of our analyses.

dependent.value:
Participants will be asked to judge others who choose the other possible position on the two issues on the following:
-unintelligent (1 = strongly disagree, 5 = strongly agree)
-irrational (1 = strongly disagree, 5 = strongly agree)
-ignorant (1 = strongly disagree, 5 = strongly agree)
-bad moral character (1 = strongly disagree, 5 = strongly agree)
-unethical (1 = strongly disagree, 5 = strongly agree)
-immoral (1 = strongly disagree, 5 = strongly agree)
The first three items above will be averaged to form a composite measuring intellectual capabilities, and the latter three will be averaged to form a composite measuring moral character.

Participants will also rate, on 5-pt scales (1 = strongly disagree, 5 = strongly agree), the extent to which they agree or disagree with the following two statements: (1) people who choose the same position as me have good reasons for choosing the position; and (2) people who choose the other position have good reasons for choosing their position. We refer to the former measure as goodness of supporters’ reasons, and we refer to the latter measure as goodness of opponents’ reasons.

conditions.value: There are no conditions to which participants will be assigned. Participants will see all three political issues and make all ratings for each issue.

hypothesis.value: There are two main hypotheses. First, we hypothesize that people believe that their opponents lack good reasons for their positions (relative to those who hold the same position as themselves) for each of the two political issues examined: concealed carry of handguns and universal healthcare. Second, we hypothesize that the more people believe their opponents lack good reasons for their positions, the more they derogate the intellectual capabilities and moral character of those opponents.

To address this, we will conduct separate zero-order correlations, split by political issue, between our variables.

Participants will be asked the following: “Do you feel that you paid attention, avoided distractions, and took the survey seriously?” They respond by selecting one of the following: (1) no, I was distracted; (2) no, I had trouble paying attention; (3) no, I didn’t not take the study seriously; (4) no, something else affected my participation negatively; or (5) yes. Participants will be ensured that their responses will not affect their payment or their eligibility for future studies. Only those participants who select (5) will be included in any of our analyses.
registration_responses.dependent:
Participants will be asked to judge others who choose the other possible position on the two issues on the following:
-unintelligent (1 = strongly disagree, 5 = strongly agree)
-irrational (1 = strongly disagree, 5 = strongly agree)
-ignorant (1 = strongly disagree, 5 = strongly agree)
-bad moral character (1 = strongly disagree, 5 = strongly agree)
-unethical (1 = strongly disagree, 5 = strongly agree)
-immoral (1 = strongly disagree, 5 = strongly agree)
The first three items above will be averaged to form a composite measuring intellectual capabilities, and the latter three will be averaged to form a composite measuring moral character.

Participants will also rate, on 5-pt scales (1 = strongly disagree, 5 = strongly agree), the extent to which they agree or disagree with the following two statements: (1) people who choose the same position as me have good reasons for choosing the position; and (2) people who choose the other position have good reasons for choosing their position. We refer to the former measure as goodness of supporters’ reasons, and we refer to the latter measure as goodness of opponents’ reasons.
registration_responses.conditions: There are no conditions to which participants will be assigned. Participants will see all three political issues and make all ratings for each issue.
registration_responses.hypothesis: There are two main hypotheses. First, we hypothesize that people believe that their opponents lack good reasons for their positions (relative to those who hold the same position as themselves) for each of the two political issues examined: concealed carry of handguns and universal healthcare. Second, we hypothesize that the more people believe their opponents lack good reasons for their positions, the more they derogate the intellectual capabilities and moral character of those opponents.

attributes.title: Reasons and Derogation of Opponents
attributes.description: Investigation of the role of reasons in person perception for the issue of concealed carry.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Reasons and Derogation: Concealed Carry with 4 Conditions

other.value:
As a secondary analysis, we will examine how many participants change their minds in each condition. We will compute cross-tabs analyses (2 x 4) to determine whether participants are more likely to change their minds (yes vs. no) when presented with reasons in opposition to their chosen option vs. when they are presented with reasons favoring their initial choices vs. no reasons whatsoever vs. when they are presented with all reasons for both sides. If significant, we will employ ransacking. 

We will also examine whether confidence changes as a function of condition (for all subjects and for the subset who do not change their minds). To this end, we will compute change in confidence scores (final confidence minus initial confidence) to serve as the DV. Condition will be the IV in the one-way ANOVA. If condition is significant in the ANOVA, we will conduct pair-wise post-hoc tests (LSD) between all possible conditions.

We will also compute the primary analyses with only the subset of participants who do not change their minds on their position.

sample.value: 900 participants will be recruited on Amazon's Mechanical Turk

analyses.value: We will conduct four separate one-way ANOVAs to start. In each model, condition (4 levels of factor) will be the IV. In one model, the intellectual capabilities of opponents composite is the DV; in another model model, the moral character of opponents composite is the DV; in another model, the intellectual capabilities of people who choose the same position as them composite is the DV; in another model, the moral character of people who choose the same position as them composite is the DV. If condition is significant in any of the 4 ANOVAs, we will conduct post-hoc tests (LSD) to see which pair-wise conditions differ.

-irrational (1 = strongly disagree, 5 = strongly agree)
-ignorant (1 = strongly disagree, 5 = strongly agree)
-bad moral character (1 = strongly disagree, 5 = strongly agree)
-unethical (1 = strongly disagree, 5 = strongly agree)
-immoral (1 = strongly disagree, 5 = strongly agree)

The first three items above will be averaged to form a composite measuring intellectual capabilities of people who choose the same position as them, and the latter three will be averaged to form a composite measuring moral character of people who choose the same position as them.

conditions.value:
There are four conditions to which participants will be randomly assigned. In all conditions, participants will read neutral background information about concealed carry, and then they will make a binary choice about whether they support or oppose a position. They will also rate confidence in the superiority of their binary decision on a 5-pt scale. 

After that, participants will be randomly assigned to one of four between-subjects conditions. In the first experimental condition, participants will be asked to consider 4 reasons for choosing the other possible position. In the other experimental condition, participants will be asked to consider 4 reasons favoring their chosen position. In another experimental condition, participants will be asked to consider 4 reasons for choosing the other possible position, and 4 reasons for favoring their chosen position. And in the control condition, participants see no reasons whatsoever.

Regardless of condition, all participants then choose their position on the same issue again (with the opportunity to change their minds), and they rate confidence again on the same scale.

hypothesis.value:
Primary Question: Does the consideration of reasons for an opposing (unchosen) position make participants less likely to derogate the intellectual capabilities and moral character of opponents (even when reasons favoring the chosen position are also presented along with the opposing reasons)--relative to being presented only with reasons favoring the same (chosen) position OR being presented with no reasons whatsoever? 

Secondary Question: Does the consideration of reasons for an opposing view, the same view, both sides, or no reasons alter how people perceive the intellectual capabilities and moral character of others who choose the same position as them.

attributes.title: Latent Correlations Between Trait Aggression and Trait Antagonism
attributes.description:
Trait aggression remains an imperfectly understood personality construct without a major theoretical framework in which to reside. In this project, I will test the prediction that the antagonism (low agreeableness) factor of the Five Factor Model (FFM) of personality will account for the overwhelming majority of the variance in trait aggression (latent correlations > .60). Other FFM factors will exhibit latent correlations < |.60|. These predictions are supported by a wealth of evidence that places antagonism at the core of aggressive behavior:

DeLisi, M. (2019). Antagonism and crime. In The handbook of antagonism (pp. 297-309). Academic Press.

Hyatt, C. S., Zeichner, A., & Miller, J. D. (2019). Laboratory aggression and personality traits: A meta-analytic review. Psychology of Violence, 9(6), 675.

Vize, C. E., Collison, K. L., Miller, J. D., & Lynam, D. R. (2020). The “core” of the dark triad: A test of competing hypotheses. Personality Disorders: Theory, Research, and Treatment, 11(2), 91.

Vize, C. E., Miller, J. D., & Lynam, D. R. (2018). FFM facets and their relations with different forms of antisocial behavior: An expanded meta-analysis. Journal of Criminal Justice, 57, 67-75.

I ran an exploratory analysis on the data of 355 undergraduates who completed the Brief Aggression Questionnaire (BAQ) and the IPIP-NEO-120. This factor analysis modeled the latent correlations between trait aggression (indicated by the Physical Aggression, Verbal Aggression, Anger, and Hostility subscales) and all five FFM factors (each factor indicated by its six underlying facets), simultaneously. This model revealed that the antagonism facet of the FFM accounted for the overwhelming majority of the variance in trait aggression (latent r = .90), whereas the other four factors only accounted for a relatively small amount of variance in trait aggression (latent rs: conscientiousness = -.29, neuroticism = .22, extraversion = -.01, openness = -.03).

I will now seek to confirm these analyses by replicating them in a combined dataset constructed from several existing laboratory studies on undergraduate participants who completed the 29-item Buss-Perry Aggression Questionnaire measure of trait aggression and the 44-item Big Five Inventory (7 studies, combined N = 893).

I will use the lavaan package for R to run factor analyses for each FFM facet using the following design:

LatentCorr.mod <- 'BPAQtotal =~ BPAQphysical + BPASverbal + BPAQanger + BPAQhostility
BFIagreeableness =~ BFI.2 +  BFI.7 +  BFI.12 +  BFI.17 +  BFI.22 +  BFI.27 +  BFI.32 +  BFI.37 +  BFI.42
BFIconscientious =~ BFI.3 +  BFI.8 +  BFI.13 +  BFI.18 +  BFI.23 +  BFI.28 +  BFI.33 +  BFI.38 +  BFI.43
BFIextraversion =~ BFI.1 +  BFI.6 +  BFI.11 +  BFI.16 +  BFI.21 +  BFI.26 +  BFI.31 +  BFI.36
BFIneuroticism =~ BFI.4 +  BFI.9 +  BFI.14 +  BFI.19 +  BFI.24 +  BFI.29 +  BFI.34 +  BFI.39
BFIopenness =~ BFI.5 +  BFI.10 +  BFI.15 +  BFI.20 +  BFI.25 +  BFI.30 +  BFI.35 +  BFI.40 +  BFI.41 + BFI.44'

fitmod <- cfa(LatentCorr.mod, data=[Dataset], missing='ML')

summary(fitmod, fit.measures=TRUE, standardized = TRUE)

I will then report the standardized latent correlations for each FFM factor. I will interpret that my hypotheses if the latent correlation between trait aggression and agreeableness is more negative than -.60, and if the latent correlations between trait aggression and the four other FFM factors are < |.60|.

attributes.title: Precarious Manhood Beliefs: Isomorphism and Links to Gender Beliefs Across Cultures
attributes.description:
It has been 30 years since a large cross-cultural study was carried out testing people's understanding of masculinity and femininity (Williams & Best, 1990).

This study is part of a larger, umbrella project that is collecting data from over 40 countries to determine how people think about men and women today.

In this project, we examine the isomorphism of a brief measure of precarious manhood beliefs. Precarious manhood beliefs are beliefs that manhood, relative to womanhood, is a social status that (1) is hard to earn, (2) is easy to lose, and (3) must be demonstrated repeatedly via public action.  

We test whether the brief, 4-item Precarious Manhood Beliefs (PMB) scale demonstrates statistical isomorphism across at least 45 (and up to 56) countries.  We also examine the unique associations of the PMB with two cross-culturally validated measures of gender beliefs: the Ambivalent Sexism Inventory (Glick & Fiske, 1996), and the Ambivalence toward Men Scale (Glick & Fiske, 1999).  Finally, we examine whether the PMB correlates with country-level indicators of gender equality (the Global Gender Gap Index) and human development (the Human Development Index).
attributes.registration_supplement: Pre-Registration in Social Psychology (van 't Veer & Giner-Sorolla, 2016): Pre-Registration

additionalComments.value: We have already conducted analyses on data collected from 45 countries.  For these data, all of our hypotheses were exploratory, as we did not pre-register them.  However, we are awaiting data from an additional 11 countries (England, South Africa, Czech Republic, Finland, Switzerland, Indonesia, Northern Ireland, Portugal, Japan, Morocco, and Iran).  Therefore, we are pre-registering our hypotheses as confirmatory, on the assumption that the full dataset (with 56 countries) will replicate the findings that we currently have.

question10b.value:
Participants completed a set of scales, in their primary language, that measured more variables than those described in this preregistration (see the forked study at osf.io/fqd4p, as well as materials attached to this preregistration, for the full set of variables).  

All scales were completed in a randomized order.  Relevant to this study, participants completed the PMB, ASI, and AMS, and reported their age and sex.

Country-level data (GGGI and HDI) were obtained from the World Economic Forum (2019) and the Human Development Reports (United Nations Development Programme, 2019).

question4b.value: Ultimately, we plan to collect no less than 55 national samples around the world (total sample N > 22,000).  All samples will be composed of undergraduate students of the social sciences to ensure comparability between samples.  The minimum assumed national sample size is n = 200, and the samples will be gender balanced.  In each country we will strive to ensure geographical diversity of the sample - if possible and reasonable, we will collect subsamples from various universities in a given country.

question5b.value:
Data collection was conducted via SurveyMonkey as a part of large cross-national project of 45 (so far) countries (see osf.io/fqd4p).  All samples were composed of undergraduate students in the social sciences, who were volunteers and were compensated in a manner consistent with their university’s IRB guidelines.  In most countries participants were either not compensated for their participation or received credit toward a course requirement or extra credit.  All participants were at least 18 years old.

Participants completed the survey individually or in groups on their respective campuses.  The scales were translated into 22 languages (Armenian, Chinese, Croatian, Danish, Dutch, English, Filipino, French, Georgian, German, Italian, Lithuanian, Norwegian, Polish, Portuguese, Romanian, Russian, Serbian, Slovak, Spanish, Turkish, Ukrainian), using the English version as the basis for all translations.  We have data thus far from a total of N = 20,764 students, and we removed data from 644 individuals (3%) who failed more than 1 of the 3 attention checks or provided incomplete data.  This left a sample (thus far) of N = 20,120 respondents (59% women) from 45 countries.  The mean age of participants is M = 23.46 years (SD = 7.23).  Data cleaning is underway for some samples, and we anticipate data from an additional 11 countries before we will proceed with final data analyses.

question6b.value: The final sample (N > 22,000) will be from 55 countries, with at least 100 women and 100 men in each country.  Justification of the sample size was based on the larger project (osf.io/fqd4p), and was not specific to the current study.  From the larger project, for level-one analyses: “The minimum number of subjects in correlation studies was estimated on the basis of Tabachnick and Fidell analysis (2007) for regression analyses and we assumed the value of 50 + 15 subjects per each predictor included.”

question7b.value: Collaborators in each country planned to stop data collection after obtaining usable data from 100 men and 100 women.  However, some exceptions apply.  For example, if a collaborator offered extra credit for completing the survey and they had a very large class (> 400), they could not ethically stop data collection after 100 men and 100 women because it would not be fair to deny extra credit to some students.  In some countries, collaborators collected data from more than one university in order to achieve adequate geographical diversity; this may result in more than 100 men and 100 women in those countries.  Further, in countries in which data collection proved difficult, the minimum number was not reached.  Given the initial goal of including as many countries around the world as possible, and given that there are multiple collaborators in some countries, the sample size per country varies widely from a minimum of N = 178 (Nigeria) to a maximum of N = 1864 (Germany; see Table 1).

question8b.value: We will remove the data of participants who fail more than 1 (of 3) attention checks, or who provide incomplete data on key variables (PMB, ASI, AMS).  Outliers will also be excluded.

question9b.value: Data have been collected, and no data integrity issues arose.  We thus do not anticipate needing to stop the study at this point.  However, on March 11, 2020, the World Health Organization declared COVID-19 a pandemic.  Given this, we may examine the data for indications that global concerns about the virus have affected responses to the survey.

question7c.value: We will only use complete cases on the variables of interest.

question8c.value: Internal consistency reliability coefficients will be computed for PMB measured in each country.  We will consider removing from analyses any national samples with alpha < 0.6.

question1a.value:
Hypothesis 1: PMB will demonstrate metric isomorphism.  That is, PMB will manifest as the same latent construct at both the individual and country levels.  To test the strong metric isomorphism of the PMB we will fit (using absolute fit statistics) a model in which we constrain the item loadings to be equal across levels.  We will control for age and gender distribution in the single-level one-factor model, given that these factors vary across samples.

Hypothesis 2 pertains to the associations of PMB with other cross-culturally validated gender ideologies (HS, BS, HM, and BM).  We divide it into three sub-hypotheses.

Hypothesis 2a: PMB constitutes a unique cultural belief about manhood that is not redundant with hostility and benevolence toward women or men.  To test this, we will examine if a five-factor model, in which PMB, HS, BS, HM, and BM form separate dimensions, fits the data better than alternate (e.g., one-factor and three-factor) models.  

Hypothesis 2b: A five-factor gender beliefs model – in which PMB, HS, BS, HM, and BM form separate dimensions – will demonstrate metric isomorphism across the individual and country levels.  To test this, we will use a multilevel confirmatory factor analysis approach.  

Hypothesis 2c: PMB correlates significantly and moderately positively with HS, BS, HM, and BM (controlling for age and gender distribution, which vary across samples).  Thus, countries (and individuals) higher in beliefs that manhood is precarious should also score higher in hostility and benevolence toward women and men, and these associations will emerge when other relevant third variables are controlled.

Hypothesis 3 pertains to the associations of PMB with country-level gender inequality (GGGI) and human development (HDI).  However, due to the high association of GGGI and HDI, we will analyze their associations with PMB in separate models; hence, we divide H3 into two sub-hypotheses.

Hypothesis 3a: PMB will correlate significantly and positively with country-level gender inequality (the GGGI), even when controlling for HS, BS, HM, and BM.  Thus, countries with more patriarchal social structures and larger gaps between women’s and men’s access to power and resources (higher GGGIs) will also score higher in beliefs that manhood is precarious (PMB).  This effect should persist when controlling for other gender-relevant ideologies (HS, BS, HM, BM).

Hypothesis 3b: PMB will correlate significantly and negatively with country-level human development (the HDI), even when controlling for HS, BS, HM, and BM.  Thus, more developed countries (higher life expectancy, more access to education, and more economic growth, which combine to form higher HDI) will score lower in beliefs that manhood is precarious (PMB).  This effect should persist when controlling for other gender-relevant ideologies (HS, BS, HM, BM).

question2a.value: We do not predict any interaction effects.

question3a.value: We are not manipulating any variables.

question5a.value:
Hypothesis 1: PMB will demonstrate metric isomorphism.  That is, PMB will manifest as the same latent construct at both the individual and country levels.  

Rationale: Isomorphism refers to the similarity of a latent construct’s statistical properties (i.e., measurement invariance) across levels of data (in this case, individual-level and country-level).  When a scale demonstrates metric isomorphism, this means that the latent construct under investigation is similar in measurement and meaning at both the individual and country levels.  Demonstrating the isomorphism of PMB allows researchers to use the country-level latent PMB factor score as an indicator of a property that is attributable to that nation or culture.  Thus, establishing the isomorphism of the PMB will allow examinations of the universality of precarious manhood beliefs, as well as links of PMB with other country-level variables.

Hypothesis 2a: PMB constitutes a unique cultural belief about manhood that is not redundant with hostility and benevolence toward women or men.  To test this, we will examine if a five-factor model, in which PMB, HS, BS, HM, and BM form separate dimensions, fits the data better than alternate models (e.g., one-factor and three-factor models).  

Hypothesis 2b: A five-factor gender beliefs model – in which PMB, HS, BS, HM, and BM form separate dimensions – will demonstrate metric isomorphism across the individual and country levels.  To test this, we will use a multilevel confirmatory factor analysis approach.  

Hypothesis 2c: PMB correlates significantly and moderately positively with HS, BS, HM, and BM (controlling for age and gender distribution, which vary across samples).  Thus, countries (and individuals) higher in beliefs that manhood is precarious should also score higher in hostility and benevolence toward women and men, and these associations will emerge when other relevant third variables are controlled.

Rationale: Cross-cultural studies indicate that ambivalent (hostile and benevolent) ideologies about women and men emerge from and reflect universal aspects of gender relations (status differences, sex-based labor divisions, and heterosexual interdependence).  Thus, demonstrating unique associations of PMB with HS, BS, HM, and BM, will indicate that beliefs about precarious manhood constitute a universal understanding of the male gender role that overlaps with, but is distinct from, these other widespread gender ideologies. 

Hypothesis 3a: PMB will correlate significantly and positively with country-level gender inequality (the GGGI), even when controlling for HS, BS, HM, and BM.  Thus, countries with more patriarchal social structures and larger gaps between women’s and men’s access to power and resources (higher GGGIs) will also score higher in beliefs that manhood is precarious (PMB).  This effect should persist when controlling for other gender-relevant ideologies (HS, BS, HM, BM).

Hypothesis 3b: PMB will correlate significantly and negatively with country-level human development (the HDI), even when controlling for HS, BS, HM, and BM (see Figure 1, in "PM isomorphism and HDI.docx").  Thus, more developed countries (higher life expectancy, more access to education, and more economic growth, which combine to form higher HDI) will score lower in beliefs that manhood is precarious (PMB).  This effect should persist when controlling for other gender-relevant ideologies (HS, BS, HM, BM).

Rationale: The GGGI reveals country-level gaps between women’s and men’s educational attainment, economic and political power, and health.  Countries with larger GGGIs tend to have more patriarchal social structures and traditional sex-based labor divisions, with men as the primary (higher status) economic providers and protectors, and women as the primary (lower status) homemakers and caretakers.  The HDI reveals country-level human potential in terms of life expectancy, access to education, and economic growth.  Countries with larger HDIs tend to allow their citizens more freedom to be and do desirable things, granting individuals more autonomy and control over their lives and outcomes.  Precarious manhood beliefs reflect cultural socialization practices that encourage boys and men to demonstrate willingness to risk their lives to protect and provide for family and ingroup.  Thus, these analyses will demonstrate that countries with higher gender inequality endorse PMB more strongly, while countries with higher human development endorse PMB less strongly (even when controlling for HS, BS, HM, and BM).

registration_responses.additionalComments: We have already conducted analyses on data collected from 45 countries.  For these data, all of our hypotheses were exploratory, as we did not pre-register them.  However, we are awaiting data from an additional 11 countries (England, South Africa, Czech Republic, Finland, Switzerland, Indonesia, Northern Ireland, Portugal, Japan, Morocco, and Iran).  Therefore, we are pre-registering our hypotheses as confirmatory, on the assumption that the full dataset (with 56 countries) will replicate the findings that we currently have.
registration_responses.description-hypothesis.question1a:
Hypothesis 1: PMB will demonstrate metric isomorphism.  That is, PMB will manifest as the same latent construct at both the individual and country levels.  To test the strong metric isomorphism of the PMB we will fit (using absolute fit statistics) a model in which we constrain the item loadings to be equal across levels.  We will control for age and gender distribution in the single-level one-factor model, given that these factors vary across samples.

Hypothesis 2 pertains to the associations of PMB with other cross-culturally validated gender ideologies (HS, BS, HM, and BM).  We divide it into three sub-hypotheses.

Hypothesis 2a: PMB constitutes a unique cultural belief about manhood that is not redundant with hostility and benevolence toward women or men.  To test this, we will examine if a five-factor model, in which PMB, HS, BS, HM, and BM form separate dimensions, fits the data better than alternate (e.g., one-factor and three-factor) models.  

Hypothesis 2b: A five-factor gender beliefs model – in which PMB, HS, BS, HM, and BM form separate dimensions – will demonstrate metric isomorphism across the individual and country levels.  To test this, we will use a multilevel confirmatory factor analysis approach.  

Hypothesis 2c: PMB correlates significantly and moderately positively with HS, BS, HM, and BM (controlling for age and gender distribution, which vary across samples).  Thus, countries (and individuals) higher in beliefs that manhood is precarious should also score higher in hostility and benevolence toward women and men, and these associations will emerge when other relevant third variables are controlled.

Hypothesis 3 pertains to the associations of PMB with country-level gender inequality (GGGI) and human development (HDI).  However, due to the high association of GGGI and HDI, we will analyze their associations with PMB in separate models; hence, we divide H3 into two sub-hypotheses.

Hypothesis 3a: PMB will correlate significantly and positively with country-level gender inequality (the GGGI), even when controlling for HS, BS, HM, and BM.  Thus, countries with more patriarchal social structures and larger gaps between women’s and men’s access to power and resources (higher GGGIs) will also score higher in beliefs that manhood is precarious (PMB).  This effect should persist when controlling for other gender-relevant ideologies (HS, BS, HM, BM).

Hypothesis 3b: PMB will correlate significantly and negatively with country-level human development (the HDI), even when controlling for HS, BS, HM, and BM.  Thus, more developed countries (higher life expectancy, more access to education, and more economic growth, which combine to form higher HDI) will score lower in beliefs that manhood is precarious (PMB).  This effect should persist when controlling for other gender-relevant ideologies (HS, BS, HM, BM).
registration_responses.description-hypothesis.question2a: We do not predict any interaction effects.
registration_responses.description-hypothesis.question3a: We are not manipulating any variables.
registration_responses.recommended-hypothesis.question5a:
Hypothesis 1: PMB will demonstrate metric isomorphism.  That is, PMB will manifest as the same latent construct at both the individual and country levels.  

Rationale: Isomorphism refers to the similarity of a latent construct’s statistical properties (i.e., measurement invariance) across levels of data (in this case, individual-level and country-level).  When a scale demonstrates metric isomorphism, this means that the latent construct under investigation is similar in measurement and meaning at both the individual and country levels.  Demonstrating the isomorphism of PMB allows researchers to use the country-level latent PMB factor score as an indicator of a property that is attributable to that nation or culture.  Thus, establishing the isomorphism of the PMB will allow examinations of the universality of precarious manhood beliefs, as well as links of PMB with other country-level variables.

Hypothesis 2a: PMB constitutes a unique cultural belief about manhood that is not redundant with hostility and benevolence toward women or men.  To test this, we will examine if a five-factor model, in which PMB, HS, BS, HM, and BM form separate dimensions, fits the data better than alternate models (e.g., one-factor and three-factor models).  

Hypothesis 2b: A five-factor gender beliefs model – in which PMB, HS, BS, HM, and BM form separate dimensions – will demonstrate metric isomorphism across the individual and country levels.  To test this, we will use a multilevel confirmatory factor analysis approach.  

Hypothesis 2c: PMB correlates significantly and moderately positively with HS, BS, HM, and BM (controlling for age and gender distribution, which vary across samples).  Thus, countries (and individuals) higher in beliefs that manhood is precarious should also score higher in hostility and benevolence toward women and men, and these associations will emerge when other relevant third variables are controlled.

Rationale: Cross-cultural studies indicate that ambivalent (hostile and benevolent) ideologies about women and men emerge from and reflect universal aspects of gender relations (status differences, sex-based labor divisions, and heterosexual interdependence).  Thus, demonstrating unique associations of PMB with HS, BS, HM, and BM, will indicate that beliefs about precarious manhood constitute a universal understanding of the male gender role that overlaps with, but is distinct from, these other widespread gender ideologies. 

Hypothesis 3a: PMB will correlate significantly and positively with country-level gender inequality (the GGGI), even when controlling for HS, BS, HM, and BM.  Thus, countries with more patriarchal social structures and larger gaps between women’s and men’s access to power and resources (higher GGGIs) will also score higher in beliefs that manhood is precarious (PMB).  This effect should persist when controlling for other gender-relevant ideologies (HS, BS, HM, BM).

Hypothesis 3b: PMB will correlate significantly and negatively with country-level human development (the HDI), even when controlling for HS, BS, HM, and BM (see Figure 1, in "PM isomorphism and HDI.docx").  Thus, more developed countries (higher life expectancy, more access to education, and more economic growth, which combine to form higher HDI) will score lower in beliefs that manhood is precarious (PMB).  This effect should persist when controlling for other gender-relevant ideologies (HS, BS, HM, BM).

Rationale: The GGGI reveals country-level gaps between women’s and men’s educational attainment, economic and political power, and health.  Countries with larger GGGIs tend to have more patriarchal social structures and traditional sex-based labor divisions, with men as the primary (higher status) economic providers and protectors, and women as the primary (lower status) homemakers and caretakers.  The HDI reveals country-level human potential in terms of life expectancy, access to education, and economic growth.  Countries with larger HDIs tend to allow their citizens more freedom to be and do desirable things, granting individuals more autonomy and control over their lives and outcomes.  Precarious manhood beliefs reflect cultural socialization practices that encourage boys and men to demonstrate willingness to risk their lives to protect and provide for family and ingroup.  Thus, these analyses will demonstrate that countries with higher gender inequality endorse PMB more strongly, while countries with higher human development endorse PMB less strongly (even when controlling for HS, BS, HM, and BM).

registration_responses.description-methods.planned-sample.quest: Ultimately, we plan to collect no less than 55 national samples around the world (total sample N > 22,000).  All samples will be composed of undergraduate students of the social sciences to ensure comparability between samples.  The minimum assumed national sample size is n = 200, and the samples will be gender balanced.  In each country we will strive to ensure geographical diversity of the sample - if possible and reasonable, we will collect subsamples from various universities in a given country.

Data collection was conducted via SurveyMonkey as a part of large cross-national project of 45 (so far) countries (see osf.io/fqd4p).  All samples were composed of undergraduate students in the social sciences, who were volunteers and were compensated in a manner consistent with their university’s IRB guidelines.  In most countries participants were either not compensated for their participation or received credit toward a course requirement or extra credit.  All participants were at least 18 years old.

Participants completed the survey individually or in groups on their respective campuses.  The scales were translated into 22 languages (Armenian, Chinese, Croatian, Danish, Dutch, English, Filipino, French, Georgian, German, Italian, Lithuanian, Norwegian, Polish, Portuguese, Romanian, Russian, Serbian, Slovak, Spanish, Turkish, Ukrainian), using the English version as the basis for all translations.  We have data thus far from a total of N = 20,764 students, and we removed data from 644 individuals (3%) who failed more than 1 of the 3 attention checks or provided incomplete data.  This left a sample (thus far) of N = 20,120 respondents (59% women) from 45 countries.  The mean age of participants is M = 23.46 years (SD = 7.23).  Data cleaning is underway for some samples, and we anticipate data from an additional 11 countries before we will proceed with final data analyses.

The final sample (N > 22,000) will be from 55 countries, with at least 100 women and 100 men in each country.  Justification of the sample size was based on the larger project (osf.io/fqd4p), and was not specific to the current study.  From the larger project, for level-one analyses: “The minimum number of subjects in correlation studies was estimated on the basis of Tabachnick and Fidell analysis (2007) for regression analyses and we assumed the value of 50 + 15 subjects per each predictor included.”

Collaborators in each country planned to stop data collection after obtaining usable data from 100 men and 100 women.  However, some exceptions apply.  For example, if a collaborator offered extra credit for completing the survey and they had a very large class (> 400), they could not ethically stop data collection after 100 men and 100 women because it would not be fair to deny extra credit to some students.  In some countries, collaborators collected data from more than one university in order to achieve adequate geographical diversity; this may result in more than 100 men and 100 women in those countries.  Further, in countries in which data collection proved difficult, the minimum number was not reached.  Given the initial goal of including as many countries around the world as possible, and given that there are multiple collaborators in some countries, the sample size per country varies widely from a minimum of N = 178 (Nigeria) to a maximum of N = 1864 (Germany; see Table 1).

attributes.title: Diabetes and hypertension care cascades in Guatemala
attributes.description: This will be a cross-sectional analysis of hypertension and diabetes care cascades among adults in the INCAP Oriente trial who participated in the cardiometabolic follow-up wave from 2015-2017.

q2.value: We hypothesize that there will be significant gaps in cascades of care for diabetes, hypertension, and cardiovascular disease risk.

q3.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This will be a secondary analysis of hypertension and diabetes care cascades among adults in the INCAP Oriente trial in Guatemala who participated in the cardiometabolic follow-up wave from 2015-2017.

q8.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

question.value: Data collection procedures are explained in further detail in this prior study: https://www.thelancet.com/journals/langlo/article/PIIS2214-109X(18)30231-6/fulltext

q11.value: We anticipate our sample size to be approximately 2300 participants with data collected and available in the last cohort wave.

question.value:
Demographic: Sex, area of residence, adult socioeconomic status score, years of schooling

Anthropometrics: height, weight, BMI, waist circumference, systolic blood pressure, diastolic blood pressure

Clinical domains: Medical diagnoses, medications, tobacco use, smoking use, family history, presence of obesity, presence of metabolic syndrome

Serum biomarkers: Lipids, hemoglobin A1c, fasting glucose, postprandial glucose.
See above. All data already has been collected.

Variable specification: I will define variables in line with previous analysis of the data in the article by Ford et al. For diagnoses of diabetes and hypertension, I also will ensure concordance with the diagnostic criteria in the contemporaneous Ministry of Health clinical guidelines. 

Statistical plan:
1.	Descriptive statistics will be generated similar to Table 1 in the previously published study. I plan to include other pertinent clinical variables listed below.
2.	Treatment care cascades for diabetes and hypertension will be created. These cascades will look similar to the Figure below. There are 151 and 159 people with diabetes and hypertension, respectively, in the cohort. This will restrict the number of cascade “bins” I can utilize.
3.	Two separate logistic regression models will be constructed to predict access to care for diabetes and hypertension. Each regression will be restricted to the subsample of participants with the disease. I will use continuous covariates preferentially to preserve power. Based on a prior study, I plan to include the following covariates a priori in the models: total grades completed, adult socioeconomic status, sex, residence, and age.

q21.value: Depending on the degree of missingness, we may follow the procedure outlined in a prior publication from this dataset: "For missing covariates, we imputed sex-specific medians for continuous variables and sex-specific modes for discrete variables. We included dummy variables, coded as 1 if the variable was missing or 0 otherwise, to account for the measurement error in the imputed covariates."

registration_responses.q17.question:
Variable specification: I will define variables in line with previous analysis of the data in the article by Ford et al. For diagnoses of diabetes and hypertension, I also will ensure concordance with the diagnostic criteria in the contemporaneous Ministry of Health clinical guidelines. 

Statistical plan:
1.	Descriptive statistics will be generated similar to Table 1 in the previously published study. I plan to include other pertinent clinical variables listed below.
2.	Treatment care cascades for diabetes and hypertension will be created. These cascades will look similar to the Figure below. There are 151 and 159 people with diabetes and hypertension, respectively, in the cohort. This will restrict the number of cascade “bins” I can utilize.
3.	Two separate logistic regression models will be constructed to predict access to care for diabetes and hypertension. Each regression will be restricted to the subsample of participants with the disease. I will use continuous covariates preferentially to preserve power. Based on a prior study, I plan to include the following covariates a priori in the models: total grades completed, adult socioeconomic status, sex, residence, and age.

attributes.title: Systematic review and meta-analysis
attributes.description: Emollient for the Primary Prevention of Atopic Dermatitis in infants: A Systematic Review and Meta-analysis of Randomized Controlled Trials

q2.value: To evaluate the effect of emollients on prevention of AD in infant

q3.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: A Systematic Review and Meta-analysis of Randomized Controlled Trials

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Two authors conducted independent data extraction and assessed study quality. A Meta-analysis was conducted to calculate the risk ratio (RR) using random-effects models

Inclusion Criteria. We included randomized controlled trials (RCTs) that met each of the following PICOS criteria: (1) infants (<1 years old) without atopic dermatitis or food allergy at the time of randomization;(2) the intervention group received emollients (regardless of duration, frequency and use of microbubbles) during intravenous thrombolysis; (3) the comparison group received no specific advice on skin care; and (4) clinical outcomes, such as atopic dermatitis or food allergy.
Exclusion Criteria.  (1) case reports, case series, and observational studies, (2) trials of preterm birth, and (3) trials of infants with congenital skin conditions.
The primary efficacy outcome was atopic dermatitis. It was diagnosed mainly according the UK Working Party diagnostic criteria or Hanifin and Rajka diagnostic criteria. Other diagnostic criteria were also acceptable. The secondary outcomes were food allergy, quality of life (EQ-5D).

We wil use Rev a 5.3.3 software (a freeware available from The Cochrane Collaboration) for all meta-analysis, with a threshold of P value of < 0.05 to determine statistical significance. Analyses for all outcomes were done on an intention-to-treat basis. We will conduct meta-analyses and pooled the effect estimates using the Mantel-Haenszel (M-H) method and presented the results in forest plots. We assessed statistical heterogeneity using the Chi2 test and the I2 test. Random effects model was applied for all meta-analysis. We assessed evidence of publication bias across studies using funnel plots if 10 or more studies were in a meta-analysis.2
Subgroup analysis
To identify potential sources of heterogeneity (when the I2 statistic was 25% or more), we a priori conducta subgroup analysis based on baseline risk of AD using the incidence of AD in control groups as predictors. To further explore the putative interactive interaction between baseline risk of AD and the magnitude of the effect, we performed a meta-regression analysis using the incidence of AD in control groups as predictors. We also a priori conduct subgroup analyses based on family history of atopic dermatitis and duration of intend treatment
Sensitivity analyses
Sensitivity analyses were conducted for the primary outcomes by (1) excluding studies with follow-up less than 1 year, (2) excluding trials published before 2015, (3) using fixed-effect models, (4) excluding trials with fewer than 200 patients, and (5) excluding trials with high risk of bias.
